overview: Here's a high-yield 6-day hypertrophy plan with evidence-based guardrails. It hits each muscle 2–3x weekly, targets ~12–20 hard sets per muscle per week, uses mostly compounds first, and builds in clear progression.

global_rules.title: Effort
global_rules.text: Stop most working sets with 0–2 reps in reserve (RIR). Take isolation accessories to 0–1 RIR on last set.

global_rules.title: Rest
global_rules.text: 2–3 min after compound sets; 60–90 s on isolation.

global_rules.title: Progression
global_rules.text: Double progression. Use the given rep range. When you hit the top of the range for all sets with the same load, increase load next time by the smallest increment.

global_rules.title: Volume tuning
global_rules.text: If lifts stall for 2 consecutive weeks and you're sleeping 7–9 h, add 1–2 sets for the lagging muscle. If performance or sleep drops, remove 2–4 weekly sets for that area.

global_rules.title: Deload
global_rules.text: Every 5–6 weeks, reduce sets by ~30–50% and load by ~10–15% for one week.

Legs A: 6) Ab wheel or plank — 3 hard sets

conditioning_and_recovery: Optional low-intensity cardio: 2×20–30 min easy pace on rest days or after lower-body days. Keep it easy to avoid interference.
Mobility: 10–15 min daily movement prep and post-session resets for hips, T-spine, shoulders.
Sleep: 7–9 h/night. Keep a consistent schedule.

nutrition.goal: gain ~0.25–0.5% of bodyweight per week. Adjust calories based on a 7–14 day rolling average of morning scale weight.
nutrition.calories: Start at maintenance +10–15%. If unknown, estimate maintenance at 32–36 kcal/kg/day for active lifters, then add 250–450 kcal/day. Adjust by ±150–200 kcal as needed to keep the weekly gain target.
nutrition.protein: 1.6–2.2 g/kg/day. Split across 3–5 feedings. Aim 0.3–0.5 g/kg per meal from high-quality sources.
nutrition.carbohydrate: 3–6 g/kg/day. Skew toward training window to fuel volume and recovery.
nutrition.fat: 0.6–1.0 g/kg/day (generally 20–35% of calories). Fill remaining calories after protein and carbs.
timing_and_training_day_setup: 2–3 h pre-workout: 0.5–1.0 g/kg carbs + 0.3 g/kg protein. Keep fats moderate.
30–60 min pre: Optional caffeine 1–3 mg/kg; add 1–2 g sodium in fluids if you sweat heavily.
Post-workout (within ~2 h): ~0.3 g/kg protein. Add 1–1.5 g/kg carbs across the next 3–6 h.
Pre-sleep: 30–40 g slow protein (e.g., casein or Greek yogurt) to support overnight MPS.
supplements: Creatine monohydrate: 3–5 g daily, any time.
Whey or casein: to hit protein targets.
Vitamin D3: 1000–2000 IU/day if intake or sun is low.
Fish oil: target 1–2 g EPA+DHA/day via supplements or fatty fish.
Optional performance adds: 6–8 g citrulline malate ~30–45 min pre; beta-alanine 3.2–6.4 g/day if doing lots of intervals or high-rep work.

hydration_and_electrolytes.fluids: 30–40 ml/kg/day baseline, plus 500–1000 ml per hour of training.
hydration_and_electrolytes.electrolytes: Include 2–3 g sodium/day minimum; more if you sweat heavily.

for_80_kg_lifter.Calories: ≈ 2,900–3,400 (adjust to hit weekly weight gain target)

execution_checklist: Track loads, reps, and bodyweight. Aim to add 1–2 reps per exercise weekly or increase load when you hit the top of the range.
Keep most sets at 0–2 RIR; push isolation last sets to 0–1 RIR.
If joints feel beat up, swap barbell work for machine or DB variations while keeping volume and effort targets.
Reassess every 4–6 weeks. If a muscle lags, add 3–4 weekly sets for it and maintain for a block.
